Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Understanding Nonlinear Mechanical Behavior in Porous Infrastructure Materials

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
This EArly-concept Grant for Exploratory Research (EAGER) project will provide enhanced understanding of the mechanical response behavior of porous infrastructure materials. Porous infrastructure materials are critical to the foundations of civilized life, from underlying structural bedrock to the tallest concrete structures in the world. Societal pressures for increased material efficiency are expanding the use and specifications of these materials. In addition, improved monitoring of such materials is necessary to extend material life, safely and economically, and ensure public safety for the nation infrastructure. However, progress toward expanding design and inspection of porous infrastructure materials is hampered because some aspects of their mechanical response behavior are poorly understood. This study addresses the gaps in existing knowledge through direct observations using new experimental techniques that can shed light on the micro-seismic initiation behavior of rock, establish a new non-linear basis to interpret vibration and wave propagation responses in concrete structures for structural health monitoring, and potentially provide new insight about time dependent material behaviors including shrinkage and creep in concrete.

Dynamic Mesoscale Nonlinear Elastic (DME) behaviors in porous infrastructure materials will be studied using innovative experimental measurements at two different length scales. The study is composed of the following efforts: (i) Design and carry out macroscale observations of material nonlinear DME behaviors through vibrational studies across environmental conditions; (ii) Design and carry out microscale observations of nonlinear DME behaviors through Environmental Scanning Electron Microscope (ESEM) measurements across environmental conditions; (iii) Evaluate the observations between the length scales to formulate a feasible basis for new physically-based phenomenological theory underlying DME behaviors. The findings of the work will provide unique insight and a new foundation to understand and interpret dynamic mechanical responses of a broad range of porous engineered materials, and as such offer benefits to broad swaths of the academic community.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Waves propagate through solid materials, and by doing so reveal fascinating complexity about the internal structure of those materials. Dynamic Mesoscale Nonlinear Elastic (DME) behavior, commonly known as slow dynamics, represents a type of complexity that exists in many materials, but a physical cause for the phenomena remains elusive.  These behaviors were observed initially in rock during vibration testing, where the stiffness of the material was affected (reduced) for a time period after a vibrational excitation was applied.  As such, these materials are known to display mechanical characteristics that are influenced by past loading history over long time durations. The universality of the slow dynamic behaviors across a wide range of materials hinders the identification of physical phenomena or material features that underlie the behavior, so identification of a physical foundation for slow dynamics behavior continues to elude researchers.  Yet a more complete understanding of these anomalous mesoscale dynamic behaviors would provide insight to an important mechanical response of solids. 

Slow dynamic DME behavior has traditionally been linked to the presence of material internal discontinuities - e.g. cracks and grain boundaries. In this work we investigated that idea. We studied slow dynamic DME behaviors using innovative experimental measurements at two different length scales to gain deeper understanding about the underlying mechanisms. One series of experiments were carried out at the macro-scale, representative of typically applied infrastructure material measurements, while a second study were carried out at the micro-scale, representative of typically applied material science measurements. The combined measurement datasets provided a consistent experimental base set of observations that helped to formulate a unified theory for previously unexplained DME behaviors.  As part of the macro-scale experimental series, a sequential impact test device was designed and constructed to perform repeated transverse vibration impact measurements over time using identical force impacts on a prismatic sample. The application of multiple high strain vibration events elicited slow dynamic conditioning behavior. The test samples were composed of portland cement paste under varying moisture conditions that had been exposed to two different levels of damage. The measurement results showed significant DME behaviors only for samples that are both damaged and exposed to partial saturation moisture conditions. As part of the micro-scale experimental series, environmental scanning electron microscope (ESEM) imaging was used to monitor the microstructure of porous material specimens during vibration tests. The ESEM provided control of both chamber pressure, relative humidity, and temperature acting on the specimen while the vibration and imaging experiments were being performed. ESEM imaging did reveal notable changes in the porous material at high humidity levels in regions of high dynamic strain. The water/air interface front was influenced by the excitation and the excitation history. Saturated pores were observed to empty during excitation and remain empty until the completion of the excitation event. Upon completion of the excitation, the rate of re-adsorption of the water in the pores was observed to follow a nonlinear response with respect to time.

Our results demonstrate a link between measured DME behaviors, presence of cracks, and the movement of moisture; existing material models cannot explain this relationship. Two key outcomes of the work were identified: 1) the magnitude of DME behaviors correlated with damage levels and environmental moisture content as revealed by macro-scale testing; and 2) fast ESEM micro-structural imaging of the water/air interface enabled the first observation of a physical or material change representing conditioning and recovery phases of DME behaviors.  Based on these outcomes, a single phenomenological relationship was proposed that was based on these observed behaviors and aligned with existing experimental studies. These findings underpin the intellectual merit of the work: previous work on understanding DME behavior have only documented links between level of damage or discontinuities within samples and DME behavior, ignoring the effect of moisture state. Our findings broaden the understanding of the physical basis that underlies nonlinear behavior in DME materials. Slow dynamic behaviors obfuscate an array of physical measurements associated with oil exploration, structural health assessment, and seismic analysis.  Other common infrastructure materials such as cements and concretes, which comprise a large portion of the built environment, also exhibit slow dynamic behavior. Thus the work also creates broader impact because an improved understanding of DME (slow dynamic) behaviors of porous materials benefit a wide variety of studies ranging from earthquake triggering models to enhanced structural health monitoring methods for infrastructure.     

 


Last Modified: 11/29/2019
Modified by: John S Popovics
